transcripts.text: Hey, Mr.  Leslie, are you able to say how you're feeling?
I know she's right here.  I think it was traumatic.  She's embarrassed.  She's never had to go through anything like this.  She had to turn herself in this morning.
Do you want to just stop here and you can stand next to him and he'll speak for you.

So, yes, you were saying it was a traumatic experience?  Yeah.  You guys have put her under a great deal of scrutiny, put her under a microscope for the last three days.  It's been embarrassing for her, for her family, and she has to deal with that.  She has no comments on that.  It's a case like any other case.  There's a presumption of innocence.  I know that they have a great, strong case with the video, but there's going to be ongoing discussions between myself and the Crown, and we'll deal with it as it comes.
You must have had no indication that this would go viral.  Was there any sort of intention or even thought that people may be hurt down below?

As I indicated, she is embarrassed by what happened.  She wished it never happened.  Of course, she would never wish anybody would be hurt.  And we will just take this through the proper course, through the right channels, through the Crown's office, and we'll go from there.

What you understand here at this point, the public outrage and concern?  Of course.  And so I understand that as well.  As a defense lawyer, how do you hypothetically defend something that seems so pretensible when you defend something on video?  How do you go about doing that?  I think you all people should know that.  As I said, we're going to have discussions with the Crown's office.  This might not go to trial.
But that's a long way down the road.
Can you speak to this, how?
this was a momentary lapse of judgment?  Did you agree with that?  Oh, man.
